revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = George McElroy | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = George Albert McElroy | birth_date = {{Birth date |1922|05|25}} | birth_place = Third Ward, [[Houston]], [[Texas]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|2006|10|07|1922|05|25}} | death_place = [[Houston, Texas]] |death_cause= respiratory failure |resting_place= [[Houston National Cemetery]] |residence= Houston, Texas, US |nationality=American |citizenship=United States | other_names = "Mr. Mac" | education = Master of Journalism | alma_mater = [[Texas Southern University|Texas State University for Negroes]] (1956)
[[Missouri School of Journalism|University of Missouri]] (1970) | occupation= [[United States Armed Forces|Armed Forces veteran]], newspaper columnist, teacher | years_active = 1938 - 2006 | employer = [[United States Navy|US Navy]], [[United States Air Force|USAF]], ''Houston Informer'', ''[[Houston Post]]'', ''[[Jet Magazine]]'', [[University of Houston]], [[Texas Southern University]] | organization = Press Club of Houston, Houston Association of Black Journalists, [[Sigma Delta Chi]], [[Omega Psi Phi]] | known_for = First African American to receive a Master of Journalism degree from the [[Missouri School of Journalism|University of Missouri]] | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = Houston, Texas | height = | weight = | title = | movement = | parents = Hugh and Philomena McElroy | spouse={{marriage|Maxine Prudhomme|1940|1946}}, {{marriage|Lucinda Martin|1950|1995}} | children=5 daughters: Madeline, Toni, Linda, Kathleen and Sherridan | family= 5 siblings: Hugh McElroy, Agatha Jones, James McElroy, Lucy Jackson and Philip McElroy
5 Grandchildren: Kevin, Kendra, Christopher, Shana and Georgette
3 Great-grandchildren | relatives = | awards = Lifetime Achievement |credits=Pioneer of African American journalists, columnist for the ''Houston Informer'' and ''Houston Post'', Head of the Journalism Department at [[Texas Southern University]] | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''George Albert McElroy''' (born 25 May 1922, [[Houston, Texas]], died 7 October 2006) was a prominent pioneering [[African-American]] journalist. Among many "firsts" achieved by McElroy, he became the first African American to earn a [[master's degree]] in [[journalism]] from the [[Missouri School of Journalism|University of Missouri]].{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/15294613/ns/us_news-life/t/george-mcelroy-columnist-reporter-dies/#.UCw8CZ2PV_A |title=George McElroy, columnist and reporter, dies - US news - Life - Race & ethnicity - NBCNews.com |publisher=MSNBC |date=2006-10-16 |accessdate=2012-08-16}} ==Early life== George McElroy was born 25 May 1922 in [[Houston, Texas]] to Hugh and Philomena McElroy.{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/houstonchronicle/obituary.aspx?page=lifestory&pid=19535518|title=George Albert McElroy Obituary: View George McElroy's Obituary by Houston Chronicle |publisher=Legacy.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}} His father, Hugh George McElroy was a highly decorated war veteran who fought in the [[Battle of San Juan Hill]] against [[Pancho Villa]] and who fought alongside General [[John J. Pershing]] and [[Theodore Roosevelt|President Theodore Roosevelt]], and later was awarded the [[Croix de Guerre]] for his bravery in service during World War I.{{cite web |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fmcbx |title=McElroy, George Albert |author=Merline Pitre |publisher=[[Texas State Historical Association]]}} George McElroy was raised in the [[Third Ward, Houston|Third Ward]] area of Houston.{{cite web|author=Serbino Sandifer-Walker |url=http://www.chron.com/opinion/outlook/article/George-McElroy-A-storyteller-history-maker-1868163.php |title=George McElroy: A storyteller, history maker - Houston Chronicle |publisher=Chron.com |date=2006-10-15 |accessdate=2012-08-16}} After graduation from St Nicholas High School, he served in the [[United States Navy]], usually stationed in Asia from 1940 to 1948, then as an information specialist at [[Ellington Air Force Base]] in [[Houston]].{{cite news |url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Pioneering-black-columnist-George-McElroy-dies-1515403.php |title=Pioneering black columnist George McElroy dies |author=Sarah Viren and Alexis Grant |newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=9 October 2006}} ==Education and fight against segregation== After he was [[Honorable discharge|honorably discharged]] from the military, McElroy returned to his still-segregated home state of Texas. Due to [[Racial segregation in the United States|segregation]] (separate, but equal) laws of the time, he was forced to attend [[Texas Southern University]] (then-called Texas State University for Negroes (TSUN)) after being denied admission to the [[University of Texas]] (UT). He had applied to the University of Texas following the landmark decision of [[Sweatt v. Painter]]. In his letter of denial from UT, he was told that UT and TSUN both offered the courses he was seeking. Being a Negro, according to segregation laws, he had to attend TSUN. He responded to the denial letter from UT stating that although the courses were offered at both universities, there was little else "equal" about the universities.{{cite book|last=Lavergne|first=Gary M.|title=Before Brown|year=2010|publisher=University of Texas Press|location=Austin, Texas, USA|isbn=978-0-292-72200-2|pages=260|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q--b6ExcLUwC&pg=PA260&lpg=PA260&dq=george+mcelroy+journalist&source=bl&ots=nx6yP1aWXR&sig=RWWhD0a61S7aN-XVUHNtqFZXnzs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EDwsUJvbPOHfyAGHx4HYBg&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=george%20mcelroy%20journalist&f=false}} McElroy sued for the right to attend UT, but ultimately earned his [[bachelor's degree]] in journalism from TSUN in 1956.{{cite web|url=http://www.brickfish.com/pages/blogs/blogview.aspx?bid=23800&returnurl=list |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130118233651/http://www.brickfish.com/pages/blogs/blogview.aspx?bid=23800&returnurl=list |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-18 |title=Brickfish Social Media: George McElroy |publisher=Brickfish.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16 }} McElroy received a [[scholarship]] from the [[Wall Street Journal]] to attend the [[Missouri School of Journalism|University of Missouri]]. In 1970, he became the first African American to earn a [[master's degree]] in journalism from the university. ==Journalism career== In 1937, McElroy landed a job as a youth column writer at the ''Informer'', the oldest African-American newspaper in Texas. He was paid $3 per column. Throughout his off-and-on 58-year tenure with the newspaper, he functioned in virtually every capacity of running the periodical. He retired in 1996, but served as ''Editor Emeritus'' until his death in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.baystate-banner.com/archives/stories/2006/10/101206-12.htm |title=Pioneering black journalist McElroy dies at age 84 |publisher=Baystate-banner.com |date=2006-10-12 |accessdate=2012-08-16}} After graduation from the University of Missouri, McElroy considered several job offers and accepted a position as a "colored sports" writer for the now-defunct [[Houston Post]] daily [[newspaper]] in 1954{{cite book|last=Dawkins|first=Wayne|title=Black Journalists: The NABJ Story|year=1997|publisher=August Press|location=United States of America|isbn=0-9635720-4-0|pages=36|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I21yBNr9eQoC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=george+mcelroy+journalist&source=bl&ots=YA3Wh8gQsg&sig=x-l4_vQiz40z2b5o874TphNiPTI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EDwsUJvbPOHfyAGHx4HYBg&ved=0CDwQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=george%20mcelroy%20journalist&f=false}} and in 1956, he became a weekly columnist.{{cite web|url=http://my.hsj.org/Schools/Newspaper/tabid/100/view/frontpage/schoolid/781/articleid/108117/newspaperid/757/A_true_pioneer_Newsman_and_mentor_George_McElroy_inspired_many_area_black_journalists.aspx |title=Insight - Houston Chronicle Classroom - A true pioneer: Newsman and mentor George McElroy inspired many area black journalists |publisher=My.hsj.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He was the first black reporter and the first black columnist at the paper which, at that time, was the largest morning newspaper in Texas.{{cite journal|title=Jet Stringer's Article in Columbia U. Journal|journal=Jet Magazine|date=15 April 1965|volume=28|issue=1|pages=44|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ysIDAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=17 August 2012}} In spite of his position as a regular columnist, his likeness in the paper above his column was a black and white sketch of his image as opposed to photos as presented for his white counterparts at the paper. In response to question to him c. 1970 from a reader of his column, McElroy responded:
The world, the nation, the state, the city are all multicolored, as in a rainbow and multiracial. A professional journalist simply cannot afford to reside in a racial-isolation ward. He must travel and he must converse and he must observe and he must be curious.
In 1960, during an annual meeting of the Houston Press Club, the club presented a skit portraying the year's presidential candidates. (McElroy was the first African American member of the club). Local television reporter [[Dave Ward (reporter)|Dave Ward]] portrayed [[Democratic Party (United States)|democratic]] candidate [[Lyndon Johnson]]. Performing in [[Whiteface (performance)|whiteface]], McElroy portrayed the role of [[Alabama]] [[governor|Gov.]] [[George Wallace]], a vigilant [[segregationist]], after no one else wanted to portray the [[Independent (politician)#United States|independent]] candidate.Gov. George Wallace is best known for his infamous attempt to block the de-segregation of the [[University of Alabama]] and four elementary schools in defiance of federal mandates. {{cite web|last=Webb|first=Debbie|title=Wallace in the Schoolhouse Door: Marking the 40th Anniversary of Alabama's Civil Rights Standoff|url=https://www.npr.org/2003/06/11/1294680/wallace-in-the-schoolhouse-door|publisher=NPR.org|accessdate=17 August 2012}} This portrayal made McElroy the first black cast member of the club's annual "Gridiron Show". Picketers lined the streets and the cast members received death threats leading to Houston mayor [[Louie Welch]] provided police protection for McElroy for 72 hours. Also in 1960, thirteen students from Texas Southern, led by Eldrewey Stearns, held a [[sit-in]] at the counter at a Houston area Weingarten store in protest of segregation using a model laid out by experienced sit-in students at [[Fisk University]]. In planning how to attract press coverage for the sit-in, they contacted McElroy for input who committed to send a photographer from ''The Informer'' and advised on calling the police themselves. This tip proved to be instrumental in the protest. Over 100 people eventually participated in the protest which ended peacefully. The Houston television and printed press coverage dubbed the event as the "first sit-in west of the Mississippi."{{cite book|last=Cole|first=Thomas R.|title=No Color Is My Kind: The Life of Eldrewey Stearns and the Integration of Houston|year=1997|publisher=University of Texas Press|location=Austin, Texas, USA|isbn=978-0-292-71198-3|pages=26–30|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aaQN9VP6NAwC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}} McElroy also served as the Texas correspondent for [[Jet Magazine]] and was elected as President of the Press Club of Houston. Throughout his career as a journalist, McElroy interviewed numerous persons of interest including [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]], [[Fidel Castro]], [[Muhammad Ali]], [[George Foreman]] and six American presidents. In a 2000 interview, McElroy stressed the continued need for black press stressing that African Americans are closer to the issues concerning their own community and he credits black press for being first in bringing the effects of crack cocaine into the limelight long before it was deemed an issue in mainstream media.{{cite book|last=Owens|first=Reginald|title=The Journal for Multi-Media History: The Black Press|year=2000|publisher=University at Albany, State University of New York|location=New York, New York|url=http://www.albany.edu/jmmh/vol3/blackpress/blackpress.html}}
We cover issues that the major dailies don't see or fail to see. We're closer to problems and concerns in our community. We see them first.
==Teaching career== Simultaneously with his journalism career, McElroy taught journalism in the Houston area for over four decades.{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Pioneering-black-columnist-George-McElroy-dies-1515403.php |title=Pioneering black columnist George McElroy dies - Houston Chronicle |publisher=Chron.com |date=2006-10-09 |accessdate=2012-08-16}} * [[Houston Independent School District|HISD]]: [[Wheatley High School (Houston)|Phyllis Wheatley High School]] * HISD: [[Yates High School|Jack Yates High School]] (1957-1969){{cite journal|title=Jet Correspondent is Co-Director of Texas Confab|journal=Jet Magazine|date=16 April 1964|volume=26|issue=1|pages=52|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r8ADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA52&lpg=PA52&dq=george+mcelroy+journalist&source=bl&ots=wxJWBcKRVe&sig=dUjTarZXoDsX-6VsNw6DbvDVeI8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=bjosUPjwH4ONyAHI_4GwDA&ved=0CEQQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=george%20mcelroy%20journalist&f=false|accessdate=16 August 2012}} ** Chairman of the Journalism Department ** Sponsored the "[[Andrew Hatcher]] Journalism Club", named after [[John F. Kennedy|President John Kennedy's]] [[press secretary]]{{cite journal|title=Texas writing students honor Andrew Hatcher|journal=Jet Magazine|date=16 February 1961|volume=19|issue=17|page=49|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KLEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA49&lpg=PA49&dq=george+mcelroy+journalist#v=onepage&q=george%20mcelroy%20journalist&f=false|accessdate=16 August 2012|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company}} * [[University of Houston]] - professor of journalism for four years * [[Texas Southern University]] - retired in 1989 ** Chair of the Journalism Department ** Professor of Journalism ==Firsts and honors== ===Firsts=== George McElroy was a pioneer for African Americans in the field of journalism. Throughout his life he became the first African American: * to earn a master's degree in journalism from the Missouri School of Journalism at the University of Missouri. * to write for the [[Houston Post]]. * with a journalism degree to teach journalism in the [[Houston Independent School District]]. * initiated into the Texas Gulf Coast Chapter of [[Sigma Delta Chi]], the national journalism fraternity.{{cite journal|title=Jet Correspondent in Tex. in Journalism Frat|journal=Jet Magazine|date=21 May 1964|volume=26|issue=6|page=47|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AMEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=george+mcelroy+journalist#v=onepage&q=george%20mcelroy%20journalist&f=false|accessdate=16 August 2012|author1=Company|first1=Johnson Publishing}} * member of the Houston Press Club{{cite web|last=Stunson|first=Charles|title=Fairchild's case: Minority Entrepreneurs|url=http://faculty.darden.virginia.edu/chaplinskys/PEPortal/Documents/Fairchild's%20Case%20Minority%20EnterpreneursENT-0012.pdf|work=Darden School Foundation|publisher=University of Virginia|accessdate=16 August 2012}} * to teach journalism at the [[University of Houston]]{{cite web|url=http://archive.thedailycougar.com/vol72/40/news/news2.html |title=News 2 - The Daily Cougar Online |publisher=Archive.thedailycougar.com |date=2006-10-16 |accessdate=2012-08-16}} * to win first place from the Texas Gulf Coast Press Association (for his editorials in the ''Informer''). McElroy was also the first minority of any race to have a regular column in a Houston newspaper{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1994_1217005/43rd-gridiron-show-to-honor-journalists-mcelroy-mu.html |title=43rd Gridiron Show to honor journalists McElroy, Murray 07/31/1994 | Archives | Chron.com - Houston Chronicle |publisher=Chron.com |date=1994-07-31 |accessdate=2012-08-16}}{{cite book|last=Zwerneman|first=Brent|title=Game of My Life|year=2003|publisher=Sports Publishing, LLC|location=United States of America|isbn=1-58261-600-0|page=84|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V2Zs89BshzIC&pg=PA84&lpg=PA84&dq=george+mcelroy+journalist#v=onepage&q=george%20mcelroy%20journalist&f=false}} ===Honors=== Throughout his life, McElroy received over 100 awards and honors including: * 2006: Houston Association of Black Journalists (HABJ) - Lifetime achievement Award (September 2006){{cite web|author=James T. Campbell |url=http://www.chron.com/opinion/outlook/article/About-Chron-Thank-you-Mr-Mac-I-was-one-who-1864209.php |title=About: Chron: Thank you, 'Mr. Mac': I was one who you inspired - Houston Chronicle |publisher=Chron |date=2006-10-22 |accessdate=2012-08-16}} * 2000: Golden Pen Award from the Black Heritage Society (for individuals making significant contributions to African American Heritage){{cite news|last=Vaughn|first=Carol E.|title=Honors for a journalist / McElroy receives Golden Pen Award|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/2000_3252369/honors-for-a-journalist-mcelroy-receives-golden-pe.html|accessdate=17 August 2012|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|date=20 September 2000}} * 1977: "George McElroy Week" was proclaimed by Houston mayor [[Fred Hofheinz]]. * 1964: Co-director of the first annual High School Reporters' Conference, held at [[Prairie View A&M University]]{{cite journal|title=Jet Correspondent is Co-Director of Texas Confab|journal=Jet Magazine|date=14 April 1964|volume=26|issue=1|pages=52|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r8ADAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=17 August 2012}} ===Scholarships=== Several journalism-related scholarships have been named in honor of George McElroy's contributions to journalism, including: * The Press Club of Houston Educational Foundation - George McElroy Distinguished Lifetime Achievement Scholarship ($1,000)[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Houston+Press+Club+Foundation+Awards+$4,000+in+College+Scholarships.-a0105194057 Press Club Scholarship 1994][http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1995_1288520/annual-press-club-gridiron-show-will-honor-longtim.html Press Club Scholarship 1995] * Houston Association of Black Journalists - George McElroy Scholarship[http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/2001_3338890/black-journalists-group-awards-scholarships-to-4.html HABJ Scholarship] * The Houston Press Club established the "George McElroy Distinguished Lifetime Achievement Scholarship" ==Other affiliations== * Member of [[Omega Psi Phi]] * President of the Houston Breakfast Club * President of the Press Club of Houston ==Military service== From 1940-1943, McElroy served in the [[United States Navy|Navy]] during [[World War II]] and served in the [[United States Merchant Marines]] from 1944 through 1945. From 1951-1952 during the [[Korean War]], he served as an [[Mass Communication Specialist|Information Officer]][http://search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?db=vadeaths&h=537825&ti=0&indiv=try&gss=pt&ssrc=pt_t13304090_p-90233741_kpidz0q3d-90233741z0q26pgz0q3d32768z0q26pgPLz0q3dpid George McElroy on Ancestry.com] at [[Ellington Air Force Base]] where he met his second wife, Lucinda Martin McElroy, who was serving as a [[Corporal]] in the [[Women in the Air Force|US Air Force]].{{cite web|url=http://www.locategrave.org/l/6212954/Lucinda-M-McElroy-TX |title=Lucinda M McElroy Houston TX Houston National Cemetery |publisher=Locategrave.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}} In 1973, McElroy was commissioned by Texas Governor [[Dolph Briscoe]] to serve as an [[admiral]] in the state's navy. He declined the commission opting to continue his journalism career. ==Personal life== McElroy was first married to the late Maxine Prudhomme. They had one child, Madeline.McElroy's children followed in his journalistic footsteps. Madeline McElroy Johnson is the Producer/Director of Radio for the Archdiocese of Galveston-Houston. [http://www.archgh.org/Radio Radio Ministry at the Archdiocese of Galveston-Houston] His second marriage was to [[United States Air Force|Air Force]] veteran Lucinda Martin in 1950 with whom he had four more daughters, Toni, Linda, Kathleen and Sherridan. George and Lucinda were married nearly 45 years until her death in 1995. Kathleen McElroy worked as an [[editor]] at the [[New York Times]] from 1991-2011. [http://fjsa.com/fjsa/hallofhonor.htm Texas A&M Former Journalism Students Association] In 2006, McElroy was hospitalized with respiratory illness. In September 2006, McElroy received word that he would be honored with the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Houston Association of Black Journalists at their [http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/2006_4185054/hilton-post-oak-set-as-site-of-anniversary-gala-as.html 20th Annual Scholarship Gala]. Although receiving medical treatment at the time, McElroy received permission from his attending physicians, and attended the event. McElroy received his award and gave his acceptance speech. Shortly after the event, McElroy fell gravely ill with [[Acute (medicine)|acute]] [[pneumonia]] and died on October 6. His funeral services were held at [http://www.stmaryshouston.net/web/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=47&Itemid=29 St. Mary of the Purification Catholic Church] and his remains were interred at [[Houston National Cemetery]] in Houston, Texas.{{cite web|url=http://www.locategrave.org/l/6150832/George-Albert-McElroy-TX |title=George Albert McElroy Houston TX Houston National Cemetery |publisher=Locategrave.org |date=1922-05-25 |accessdate=2012-08-16}} ==See also== {{Portal|Journalism}} * [[Texas Southern University#History|Texas Southern University]] * [[Sweatt v. Painter]] * [[National Association of Black Journalists|National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ)]] * [[Journalist]] * [[Columnist]] * [[Newspaper]] * [[Civic journalism]] ==Notes== {{reflist|group=Note}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://ww4.hdnux.com/photos/04/24/11/1131091/3/628x471.jpg Image of George McElroy from The Houston Chronicle] * McElroy, George and Veronica Perry. [http://digital.houstonlibrary.org/cdm/singleitem/collection/Interviews/id/398/rec/1 George McElroy Oral History], Houston Oral History Project, September 14, 1974] * [http://habj.org Houston Association of Black Journalists] * [http://originalmlkparade.org Black Heritage Society] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McElroy, George}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:American male journalists]] [[Category:Journalists from Texas]] [[Category:Editors of Texas newspapers]] [[Category:Houston Post people]] [[Category:African-American journalists]] [[Category:20th-century American educators]] [[Category:Texas Southern University faculty]] [[Category:University of Houston faculty]] [[Category:African-American educators]] [[Category:Journalism teachers]] [[Category:American naval personnel of World War II]] [[Category:American naval personnel of the Korean War]]

'''Sir George Sweeney''' (born 26 January 1946) is a retired British educator.
Educated at [[Prescot Boys' Grammar School]] and [[Hull University]] (graduating firstly with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in 1967 and then a [[Master of Arts]] degree in 1973), Sweeney began teaching in 1967; in 1983, he became Vice Principal at [[Grimsby Institute of Further & Higher Education|Grimsby College of Technology]]. In 1990, he became Principal of [[Knowsley Community College]], and retired in 2007. He was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the [[2000 Birthday Honours]] and was awarded an honorary [[Doctor of Education]] degree by the [[University of Chester]] in 2008.<ref>[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/10.1093/ww/9780199540884.001.0001/ww-9780199540884-e-36815 "Sweeney, Sir George"], ''Who's Who'' (online edition, Oxford University Press, December 2017). Retrieved 2 January 2018.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sweeney, George}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Knights Bachelor]] [[Category:English teachers]]

{{Multiple issues|section=| {{one source|date=December 2016}} {{BLP primary sources|date=December 2016}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2015}} }} {{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. --> | name = Harold Jaffe | image = Author photo2 copy 3.tif | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1942|07|08}}<ref>https://haroldjaffe.wordpress.com/about/</ref> | birth_place = [[New York City]] | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = Novelist, essayist, editor, professor | language = | nationality = American | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = Ph.D, English and American Literature | alma_mater = [[Grinnell College]] (undergraduate studies) [[New York University]] (graduate studies) | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = [[B. Traven]], [[Walter Benjamin]], [[Bertold Brecht]], [[Shusaku Endo]], [[Antonio Gramsci]], [[Clarice Lispector]], [[Paul Virilio]], | influenced = | awards = [[Pushcart Prize]] (three), National Endowment for the Arts Grant in Fiction (two), California Arts Council Grant in Fiction | signature = | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|https://haroldjaffe.wordpress.com}} | portaldisp = }}
'''Harold Jaffe''' (born July 8, 1942<ref>https://haroldjaffe.wordpress.com/about/</ref>) is an American writer of novels, short fiction, drama and essays. He is the author of 26 books, including 14 collections of fiction, four novels and two volumes of essays. He is also the editor of the literary-cultural journal [[Fiction International]]. His works have been translated into 15 languages, including German, Japanese, Spanish, Italian, French, Turkish, Dutch, Czech, and Serbo-Croatian. Jaffe is also a Professor of [[Creative Writing]], English and [[Comparative Literature]] at [[San Diego State University]].<ref>https://www.facebook.com/jaffeantijaffe</ref>
Jaffe’s fiction has appeared in such journals as Mississippi Review; City Lights Review; Paris Review; New Directions in Prose and Poetry; Chicago Review; Chelsea; Fiction;Central Park; Witness; Black Ice; Minnesota Review;Boundary 2; ACM; Black Warrior Review; Cream City Review; Two Girls’Review; and New Novel Review. His fictions have also been anthologized in Pushcart Prize; Best American Stories; Best of American Humor; Storming the Reality Studio; American Made; Avant Pop: Fiction for a Daydreaming Nation; After Yesterday’s Crash: The Avant-Pop Anthology; Bateria and Am Lit (Germany);Borderlands (Mexico); Praz (Italy); Positive (Japan); and elsewhere.
The 2004 issue of The Journal of Experimental Fiction called “The Literary Terrorism of Harold Jaffe” was devoted to his writings.
==Works==
===Novels=== * ''Mole's Pitty'' (1979) * ''Dos Indios'' (1983) * ''Othello Blues'' (1996) * ''Jesus Coyote'' (2008)
===Docufiction collections=== * ''Son of Sam'' (2001) * ''False Positive'' (2002) * ''Nazis, Sharks & Serial Killers'' (2003) * ''15 Serial Killers'' (2003) * ''Terror-Dot-Gov'' (2005) * ''Paris 60'' (2010) * ''Anti-Twitter'' (2010) * ''OD'' (2012) * ''Induced Coma'' (2014) * ''Death Cafe'' (2015) * ''Goosestep'' (2016) * ''Sacred Outcast'' (2017)
===Fiction collections=== * ''Mourning Crazy Horse'' (1982) * ''Beasts'' (1986) * ''Madonna and Other Spectacles'' (1988) * ''Eros Anti-Eros'' (1990) * ''Straight Razor'' (1995) * ''Sex for the Millennium'' (1999)<ref>http://jaffeantijaffe.sdsu.edu</ref>
===Essay collections=== * ''Beyond the Techno-Cave: A Guerrilla Writer’s Guide to Post-Millennial Culture'' (2006) * ''Revolutionary Brain'' (2012)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://haroldjaffe.wordpress.com Jaffe's Wordpress site] * [http://mfa.sdsu.edu/jaffe.htm Jaffe's faculty page at SDSU]
{{Authority control}}

{{coord|54.639|-5.817|display=title|region:GB_scale:10000}} The '''Holywood Rudolf Steiner School''' is a [[Waldorf education|Waldorf school]] located in [[Holywood]], [[County Down]], [[Northern Ireland]] which teaches children using methods inspired by [[Rudolf Steiner]]. The school is [[co-educational]], serving ages 3 to 17 with an enrollment of more than 160 students.<ref>[http://www.independentschools.com/northern_ireland/the-holywood-rudolf-steiner-school_35610.html Independent Schools Directory: The Holywood Rudolf Steiner School]. Accessed 2008-03-23.</ref>
==History== The school was founded in 1975 in two rooms at the [[Glencraig]] [[Camphill Movement|Camphill Community]] at [[Seahill]], just outside Holywood. In the early days the school moved site frequently before moving to its current site at Croft Road in Holywood in 1976. In 1979 a new building which became the school hall was added. In 1993 a new block was built comprising four new classrooms. In 1997, with the help of the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]], a new [[kindergarten]] was added. In 2000 another new block of classrooms was completed, again with National Lottery funding.
The school was granted provisional registration as an "independent school" in 1976 and final registration in 1993.<ref name=application>[http://archive.nics.gov.uk/edu/061005e-edu.htm Application for maintained status turned down], Department for Education News Release, 5 October 2006. Accessed on 2008-03-23.</ref> The school's application for "maintained status" was turned down in 2006 because the school did not take steps to meet certain statutory and other mandatory requirements. The department made no objections in principle to state funding. During negotiations senior civil servants acknowledged the benefits of breaking the Steiner School into the state sector, and drew parallels with the decision of the State to fund Irish language schools. Officials at the Department of Education in Northern Ireland have followed closely developments in England where the New Labour administration initiated steps to provide state funding for a number of Steiner Schools, a development that came to fruition under the Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition. <ref name=application/>
==Integration== Holywood's school website contends that it "has some claim to be the first fully [[Integrated Education|integrated school]] in Northern Ireland since the troubles began as it has had children from different communities sharing their culture, gifts and abilities throughout the school's history."
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.holywood-steiner.co.uk/ Official School Website] [[Category:Waldorf schools in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Secondary schools in County Down]] [[Category:Primary schools in County Down]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1975]] [[Category:Holywood]] [[Category:1975 establishments in Northern Ireland]]

revision.text:
Policy '''Impact Assessments''' (IAs) are formal, evidence-based procedures that assess the economic, social, and environmental effects of [[public policy]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Adelle|first=Camilla|author2=Weiland, Sabine |title=Policy assessment: the state of the art|journal=Impact Assessment and Project Appraisal|date=2012|volume=30|issue=1|pages=25–33|doi=10.1080/14615517.2012.663256}}</ref> They have been incorporated into policy making in the [[OECD]] countries and the [[European Commission]].
Key types of impact assessments include global assessments (global level), policy impact assessment (policy level), strategic environmental assessment (programme and plan level), and [[environmental impact assessment]] (project level). Impact assessments can focus on specific themes, such as [[social impact assessment]]s and gender impact assessments.
IAs can improve legislation by:<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jacob|first=Klaus|author2=Ferretti, Johanna |author3=Guske, Anna-Lena |author4=Turnpenny, John |author5=Jordan, Andrew |author6= Adelle, Camilla |title=Sustainability in Impact Assessments A Review of Impact Assessment Systems in selected OECD countries and the European Commission|journal=OECD|date=2011|volume=SG/SD(2011)6/FINAL|url=http://www.oecd.org/gov/regulatory-policy/Sustainability%20in%20impact%20assessment%20SG-SD%282011%296-FINAL.pdf|accessdate=2012-12-10}}</ref> * Informing policy makers about potential economic, social, and environmental ramifications * Improving transparency so that contributions to sustainability and "better regulation" are disclosed and [[Special Interest Group|special interest]] [[lobbying]] is discouraged * Increasing public participation in order to reflect a range of considerations, thereby improving the legitimacy of policies * Clarifying how public policy helps achieve its goals and priorities through policy indicators * Contributing to continuous learning in policy development by identifying causalities that inform ex-post review of policies
== Procedure == The department which is responsible for the policy proposal usually has to carry out the IA. Although the purpose and orientation of IA procedures differ, IA guidelines in the various jurisdictions all follow a similar set of steps to be followed by desk officers: # Planning of the IA # Carrying out the impact analysis # Consultation of affected stakeholders and the general public # Coordination with affected departments # Summary and presentation of findings in a report # Forwarding findings to decision makers # Publication of the IA report (not in all countries)
The analytical steps, which mainly relate to step 2, can be set out as i. Problem definition ii. Definition of policy objectives iii. Development of policy options iv. Analysis of impacts v. Comparison of policy options and recommendation of one option vi. Defining monitoring measures.
== Methods == Throughout the IA process, methods can be used for support. In recent years governments have increasingly invested in developing and applying methods and tools for IA.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Podhora|first=Aranka |author2=Helming, K |author3=Adenäuer, L. |author4=Heckelei, T. |author5=Kautto, P. |author6=Reidsma, P. |author7=Rennings, K. |author8=Turnpenny, J. |author9=Jansen, J.|title=). The policy-relevancy of impact assessment tools: Evaluating nine years of European research funding|journal=Environmental Science & Policy|date=2013|volume=31|pages=85–95|doi=10.1016/j.envsci.2013.03.002}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Nilsson|first=Mans|author2=Jordan, Andrew |author3=Turnpenny, John |author4=Hertin, Julia |author5=Nykvist, Björn |author6= Russel, Duncan |title=The use and non-use of policy appraisal tools in public policy making: an analysis of three European countries and the European Union|journal=Policy Sciences|date=2008|volume=41|pages=335–355 |doi=10.1007/s11077-008-9071-1}}</ref> Depending on usage, IA methods can be classified as methods for * Scoping (e.g., checklists) * For qualitative analysis (e.g., [[focus groups]]) * For quantitative analysis (e.g., [[life-cycle assessment]], [[material flow accounting]], modelling) * Aggregation and comparison of options (e.g., [[cost–benefit analysis]]) * Analysing coherence (e.g., Gender IA) * Supporting participation and involvement (e.g., internet consultation) * Data presentation and involvement (e.g., [[GIS]]) * [[Monitoring and evaluation]] (e.g., indicators)<ref>{{cite web|last=LIAISE – Network of Excellence|title=LIAISE KIT – Knowledge for Decision Making|url=http://www.liaise-kit.eu/|accessdate=2013-05-05}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Impact evaluation]] * [[Outcomes theory]] * [[Participatory impact pathways analysis]] * [[Policy analysis]] * [[Policy studies]] * [[Program evaluation]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://www.iaia.org/ International Association for Impact Assessment] (main source) * [http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/tiap20/current#.UkCBKyEo5aE Impact Assessment and Project Appraisal] (a journal) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080209004736/http://ec.europa.eu/governance/impact/index_en.htm Impact Assessment Page at the European Commission] * [http://www.iaia.org/iaiawiki IAIA Wiki]
[[Category:Impact assessment| ]] [[Category:Philosophy of science]] [[Category:Educational evaluation methods]]

[[File:Jerry-Farber-in-2013.jpg|right|thumb|Farber in 2013|alt=Photo of Jerry Farber in 2013.]]'''Jerry Farber''' (born 1935) is an American educator and writer.
==Career== Long a professor of English and Comparative Literature at [[San Diego State University]], Farber taught subsequently for seven years in the English Department at the [[University of San Diego]]. He is widely known as the author of a 1967 anti-establishment essay, "[[The Student as Nigger]]," in which he likened the student-professor relationship in American universities to that of slave and master. This piece, based on his experience as a teacher and as an often-arrested activist in the civil rights movement, served as the title essay of his first book. Subsequent books were ''The University of Tomorrowland'' and ''A Field Guide to the Aesthetic Experience''. Since then he has published essays that include "The Third Circle: On Education and Distance Learning," "What Is Literature? What Is Art? Integrating Essence and History," "Toward a Theoretical Framework for the Study of Humor in Literature and the Other Arts," "Teaching and Presence," and "On Not Betraying Poetry." Farber’s short story “Gorman,” which appeared in his first book, was included in ''The Year’s Best Science Fiction No. 4'', edited by [[Brian Aldiss]] and [[Harry Harrison (writer)|Harry Harrison]].
As a child, Farber was a radio actor and also appeared as Fleance in Orson Welles’s film version of [[Macbeth]]. A member of the 500 Club, made up of child actors who had each appeared in over 500 radio shows, Farber initiated the role of Stevie Kent, president of the Beverly Hills Beavers, on [[The Jack Benny Program]]. Among the other radio shows on which he appeared were [[The Great Gildersleeve]], [[Lux Radio Theatre]], [[The Screen Guild Theatre]], [[The Mercury Theatre on the Air]], and [[Suspense]]. In addition, he performed in a number of radio adaptations of literary works—appearing as [[David Copperfield]] on Favorite Story, as [[Huckleberry Finn]] on [[NBC University Theater]], and as [[Oliver Twist]], together with [[Basil Rathbone]] as Fagin, on [[Stars over Hollywood (radio program)|Stars Over Hollywood]]. He played Oliver Twist again, with Rathbone, on a [[Columbia Records]] album.
==Civil rights movement participation== In the civil rights movement, Farber was a member of the Non-Violent Action Committee (N-VAC), which was formed as a more militant alternative to the [[Congress of Racial Equality]], and which was active in fighting job discrimination in [[Los Angeles]]. He was arrested seven times during this period, serving a number of jail sentences, and was arrested on one further occasion for participating in an anti-[[Vietnam War]] demonstration against [[The Dow Chemical Co.]], which supplied napalm to the U.S. military. He was present as an observer for N-VAC throughout the Watts Rebellion (often referred to as the [[Watts Riots]]) in 1965. His account of this event was first published in the L.A. Free Press and has since been reprinted in ''Reporting Civil Rights'', published by the [[Library of America]].
== External links == * [http://www.sandiego.edu/cas/english/faculty/biography.php?ID=788 USD] * [http://library.uncg.edu/dp/crg/personBio.aspx?c=466 Civil Rights Greensboro: Jerry Farber]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Farber, Jerry}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Comparative literature academics]] [[Category:American male radio actors]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:Literary critics of English]] [[Category:Literature educators]] [[Category:San Diego State University faculty]] [[Category:American academics of English literature]]

revision.text:
'''Josias Priest''' (''c.'' 1645 – 3 January 1735 in [[Chelsea, London]]) was an [[England|English]] dancer, dancing-master and [[Choreography|choreographer]].
==Biography== In 1669, Priest was arrested along with four others for dancing and making music without a license. In 1668, he was a dancing-master in [[Holborn]], and in 1675 he moved to [[Leicester Fields]] to run a [[boarding school]] for [[Gentleman|gentlewomen]]. In 1680 he started a similar school at Gorge's House in [[Chelsea, London]]. Here Priest <!--(sic)--> hosted [[opera]]s, including [[John Blow]]'s ''[[Venus and Adonis (opera)|Venus and Adonis]]'' (1684) and [[Henry Purcell]]'s ''[[Dido and Aeneas]]'' (1689). It is widely believed that Priest choreographed dances for these and other semi-operas by Purcell, including ''[[Dioclesian]]'', ''[[The Fairy-Queen]]'', ''[[The Indian Queen (opera)|The Indian Queen]]'', and ''[[King Arthur (opera)|King Arthur]]'' ; however, the evidence is not entirely conclusive.
In 1699 [[Thomas Bray]] published a collection of dance music which included music for dances by Josias Priest and his son, Thomas Priest. Only one dance by Priest survives, a 'Minuet by Mr Preist'<!--Please do not change this spelling, Preist is correct--> in ''An Essay for the Further Improvement of Dancing'' (1711) published by Edmund Pemberton. References to Priest's choreography remain in some musical sources, however. The surviving minuet is for twelve women and uses a limited step vocabulary of [[minuet step]]s forwards, backwards and sideways, the main choreographic interest being in the floor patterns. It is recorded in a simplified form of [[Beauchamp-Feuillet notation]] that was typically used for recording [[English country dance]]s.<ref>A [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=musdi&fileName=134/musdi134.db&recNum=32&itemLink=r?ammem/musdibib:@field(NUMBER+@band(musdi+134)) facsimile of Priest's choreography] can be found at The Library of Congress' [[An American Ballroom Companion]]</ref>
==Notes== <references/>
==References== *Jennifer Thorp. "Josias Priest", ''[[Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians|Grove Music Online]]'', ed. L. Macy (accessed July 22, 2006), [http://www.grovemusic.com/ grovemusic.com] (subscription access).
{{DEFAULTSORT:Priest, Josias}} [[Category:Baroque dance]] [[Category:1640s births]] [[Category:1735 deaths]] [[Category:English choreographers]] [[Category:English male dancers]] [[Category:People from Chelsea, London]] [[Category:Dance education]] [[Category:17th-century dancers]]

{{Infobox company | name = Leisure Learning Unlimited, Inc. | logo = | type = [[Private company]] | foundation = [[Houston]] (1979) | location = [[Houston]], [[Texas]], [[United States|USA]] | industry = Continuing education, adult education | homepage = {{URL|http://www.Llu.com}} (Note: This company no longer exists.) }}
'''Leisure Learning Unlimited, Inc.''' is a privately owned continuing-education firm in [[Houston]], [[Texas]], which after operating for nearly four decades, ceased to function normally during the first quarter of 2017. Established in 1979 by Ted Weisgal and Kathy Kamin, Leisure Learning Unlimited (LLU) offered non-credit courses for people interested in taking up new hobbies, getting exercise and recreation, enhancing their careers, and socializing. The face-to-face classes stopped and the online classes were supposed to be offered by a new business.
== Office, main campus and external class locations ==
Leisure Learning's main campus (and its offices and Computer Center) is in Southwest Houston at 6363 Richmond Avenue. Many LLU instructors convene classes at their businesses and homes, particularly the cooking and music instruction classes. Excursions such as hiking, biking, and kayaking, take place at outdoor venues.
== Leisure Learning class schedule ==
LLU prints and distributes its schedule every two and a half months. It is on display in approximately 1,000 locations across the city. The publication racks are usually located at the entrances of restaurants, retail stores, grocery stores, and nightclubs. Several county, municipal, and school system libraries also stock the schedules.
== Variety of classes ==
In a recent course schedule, LLU offered 1,129 sessions of 478 classes on a wide array of subjects, including arts and crafts; fine arts; book and film discussion; cooking and nutrition; do-it-yourself home and vehicle repair; social dancing; photography; computer skills; instrumental and vocal music; travel; relationship advice; business; financial planning; and sports, recreation and fitness.
== Leisure Learning student base ==
As of March 2009, over 11,000 Houston-area residents have taken 20 or more courses from LLU. Of those repeat students, more than 1,200 have taken 50 classes. The large student base and word-of-mouth promotion contribute to LLU's visibility in the greater Houston community.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.ssqq.com/stories/advent33.htm A detailed history of Leisure Learning Unlimited written by SSQQ Dance Center owner Rick Archer] * [http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2006_4042054 ''Houston Chronicle'' article containing information about Leisure Learning Unlimited]
[[Category:Continuing education]] [[Category:Education in Houston]]

{{more citations needed|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox college | name = Manipal College of Medical Sciences | established = 1994 | location = Phulbari (Hospital)
[[Pokhara]], [[Nepal]] | logo = [[File:Manipal Logo.jpg]] | image = Manipal Teaching Hospital.jpg | image_size = 300px | motto = Inspired by Life | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] | type = [[Private university|Private]] | parent = [[Kathmandu University]] | head_label = Management | head = Manipal Education and Medical Group (MEMG) | free_label = Alumni | free = Society of Ex-Manipal Students (SEMS-Pokhara) | dean = Dr. B. M. Nagpal | director = Dr. P. K. Chakraborty (hospital director) | affiliations = [[Kathmandu University]] | website = {{URL|http://www.manipal.edu.np}} |city=}} '''Manipal College of Medical Sciences''' (MCOMS) is a private [[medical college]] located at [[Pokhara]], in [[Nepal]]. It is associated with [[Manipal Teaching Hospital]], and enrols about 145 students each year for the [[MBBS]] medical qualification. ==Senior staff== *Dean: Brig. Dr. B. M. Nagpal *Director Academics (Clinical Sciences): Dr. V. M. Alurkar *Director Academics (Basic Sciences): Brig. Dr. O. P. Talwar *Director (Basic Sciences): Lt. Col. Dr. S. Gokhale *Hospital Director: Dr. P. K. Chakraborty ==Location== MCOMS has two locations in [[Pokhara]]. The basic sciences campus is located at Deep Heights, and 1st and 2nd year courses are taught there. The administrative block is also located at Deep Heights. The clinical campus with the teaching hospital, is located at Phulbari, Pokhara, overlooking the [[Annapurna]] mountain range. ==Courses== *Post-graduation *[[MBBS]] *PCL Nursing *B.SC. Nursing (started 2009) ===MBBS=== The annual enrolment for the MBBS degree is 135 students (data from 2016). The majority of the students are of Nepalese and Indian origin. Students from other nations such as: Sri Lanka, United States of America (NRN), Canada (NRN), etc. are also enrolled. Many elective students visit from American and European Universities and have the opportunity for hands on training. Subjects covered: *[[Anatomy]] *[[Biochemistry]] *Community Medicine-Part I *[[Microbiology]] *[[Pathology]] *[[Pharmacology]] *[[Physiology]] The basic science training takes place at Deep Campus. After passing all the subjects of basic sciences, a student is promoted to the clinical aspect of the course. The next five semesters are devoted to the study of clinical sciences, and are held at Manipal Teaching Hospital, Pokhara. The students are intensively trained and evaluated. The third year university examinations are held at the end of the 7th semester, and include the following subjects: *Community Medicine-Part II *[[Forensic Medicine]] *[[Ophthalmology]] *[[Otorhinolaryngology]] After the successful completion of all 4 subjects of the third year, a student is allowed to take the final year examinations which consist of: *[[Medicine]] and allied subjects (Part I & II) *[[Surgery]] and allied subjects (Part I & II) *[[Obstetrics]] and [[Gynecology]] *[[Pediatrics]] ==Recognition== MCOMS is recognised by the Medical Council of Nepal, Sri Lanka, and other countries. It is also recognized by [[WHO]] and under [[FAIMER]].{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} ==Hospital== [[Manipal Teaching Hospital]] (MTH) is a 700-bedded hospital, located at Phulbari, Pokhara. The 5-storey hospital building houses an extensive medical library, students classrooms, a canteen, the main atrium, an auditorium along with outpatient departments and inpatient wards. All the medical students and faculty reside close by in other buildings. ===Treatment cost=== Treatment cost is reasonably affordable. Most tests and interventions are cheaper than that of government hospitals. There is also a Poor Patients' Fund (PPF) that provides free treatment to poor patients.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} ===Poor Patients' Fund (PPF)=== Also known as Asha, the PPF is an [[NGO]] managed by the students (mainly the 5th semester students). Funds are raised by the students by various means such as organizing movie shows, dances, college fetes, sales of T-shirts and sweat shirts, donations from the students and faculty, etc. The fund supports the cost of treatment of those patients who are unable to afford it themselves. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.manipal.edu.np/Pages/welcome.aspx Manipal College website] [[Category:Medical colleges in Nepal]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Nepal]] [[Category:Manipal Education and Medical Group]] [[Category:Education in Pokhara]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox organization | name=National Examinations Council | abbreviation=NECO | type=Examination body | image = Neco official banner.jpg | services=[[Senior Secondary Certificate Examination|SSCE]], [[JSCE]], and [[NCEE]] examinations | region_served=Nigeria | formation={{Start date and age|df=yes|1999|04}} | leader_title=Registrar | leader_name=Prof. Charles Uwakwe
| website={{official|http://www.mynecoexams.com}} | purpose= Educational | footnotes= }} The '''National Examinations Council''' (also known as NECO) is an examination body in [[Nigeria]] that conducts the [[Senior Secondary Certificate Examination]] and the General Certificate in Education in June/July and December/January respectively.
== History ==
NECO was created by former Head of State [[Abdulsalami Abubakar]] in April 1999.<ref name="neco">{{cite web|url=http://www.neconigeria.org/corporate/about.html |title=National Examinations Council (NECO): Introduction |publisher=Neconigeria.org |date=2003-10-30 |accessdate=2014-05-14}}</ref> It was the first Federal organization to offer subsidized registration to academic candidates in Nigeria.
=== Mandates ===
NECO was mandated to take over the responsibilities of the National Board of Education Measurement (NBEM). Its maiden examination took place in mid-2000.<ref name="neco"/>
== Administration ==
It is headed by a Registrar, [[Charles Uwakwe]], appointed by the President under section 9(1) of its establishing Act.<ref>[http://www.neconigeria.org/corporate/organo.html NECO official website]</ref> It has six departments, each headed by a director. Each Department has divisions, composed of units. A team of directors and a registrar are the governing body, which is headed by chair Paddy Njoku.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/fg-constitutes-boards-of-fmbn-fcda-neco-son-others/135004/ |title=FG Constitutes Boards of FMBN, FCDA, NECO, SON, Others, Articles |publisher=Thisday Live |date=2013-01-01 |accessdate=2014-05-14}}</ref>
=== Senior Secondary Certificate Examination (internal and external) ===
Nigeria offers six years of basic education, three years of junior secondary education, three years of senior secondary education, and four years of tertiary education. Mathematics and English language are compulsory though Mathematics may not be required for some courses in higher institutions.
=== Junior Secondary Certificate Examination (JSCE) ===
Junior Secondary Certificate exams are intended for candidates in the 3rd year of their junior secondary education in Federal Unity College and other Federal secondary schools. Private secondary schools also take part in JSCE. In state secondary schools, JSCE examinations are conducted by the state government.
=== National Common Entrance Examination ===
The National Common Entrance Examination is administered to pupils in their 6th year of basic education for admission into Federal Unity Colleges. Two examinations are held annually.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neconigeria.org/corporate/organo.html |title=NECO Administrative Structure |publisher=Neconigeria.org |date=2003-10-30 |accessdate=2014-05-14}}</ref>
On 15 July 2013, Some plans where made by the federal government of Nigeria to remove the National Examination Council (NECO) From the Nigeria Education System due to low and average passing percentage from candidates across the state in Nigeria
== External links ==
* {{official website|http://www.mynecoexams.com}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Education in Nigeria]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Nigeria]]

revision.text:
A '''Nodal Point''' in UK school admissions over-subscription criteria is a defined geographical location, used as a form of catchment to ensure a school not only serves pupils close to the school but also others slightly further away with little or no priority access to other schools.<ref name="AdmissionsGuidance">{{cite web |title=Free school admissions guidance |url=https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/389813/Free_School_Admissions_Guidance.pdf |publisher=Department for Education |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref> In these cases distance from a child's home to the nodal point is used for prioritising admissions, instead of distance to the school itself. Nodal points can also be known as '''Admissions Points''' or '''Centroid Points'''.<ref name="EuropaSchool">{{cite web |title=Admissions Policy for Europa School UK |url=https://www2.oxfordshire.gov.uk/cms/sites/default/files/folders/documents/childreneducationandfamilies/educationandlearning/schools/admissionpolicies/4002_1516.pdf |website=Oxfordshire.gov.uk |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref><ref name="SandwellAcademy">{{cite web |title=Sandwell Academy Centroid Points |url=https://www.sandwellacademy.com/Uploads/documents/Y7%20Admissions/Sandwell%20Academy%20Centroid%20Points%202019.pdf |publisher=Sandwell Academy |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref>
The term nodal point is also sometimes used within admissions policies to define a specific location ''on school premises'' to which home-school distance will be measured.<ref name="TurnhamAcademy">{{cite web |title=Turnham Academy Admission Arrangements 2019/2020 |url=https://www.stepacademytrust.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/Turnham-Admission-Arrangements-2019-2020.pdf |publisher=Turnham Academy |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref><ref name="FairlawnPrimary">{{cite web |title=Admissions Policy |url=http://www.fairlawn.lewisham.sch.uk/admissions/ |publisher=Fairlawn Primary School |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref>
== Usage == Nodal admissions points are used by some [[local authorities]] to mitigate the effects of the [[Greenwich Judgement]] on their statutory duty to provide sufficient school places for local children.<ref name="sandwellNodalPoints">{{cite web|title=Sandwell Academy Initiative Update|url=https://cmis.sandwell.gov.uk/Cmis5/Document.ashx?czJKcaeAi5tUFL1DTL2UE4zNRBcoShgo=4RzqTG71KAzZ5tikWqHd9gOM1t44r5ruofYMfEzN07r3%2B2I5mNzGAw%3D%3D&rUzwRPf%2BZ3zd4E7Ikn8Lyw%3D%3D=pwRE6AGJFLDNlh225F5QMaQWCtPHwdhUfCZ%2FLUQzgA2uL5jNRG4jdQ%3D%3D&mCTIbCubSFfXsDGW9IXnlg%3D%3D=hFflUdN3100%3D&kCx1AnS9%2FpWZQ40DXFvdEw%3D%3D=hFflUdN3100%3D&uJovDxwdjMPoYv%2BAJvYtyA%3D%3D=ctNJFf55vVA%3D&FgPlIEJYlotS%2BYGoBi5olA%3D%3D=NHdURQburHA%3D&d9Qjj0ag1Pd993jsyOJqFvmyB7X0CSQK=ctNJFf55vVA%3D&WGewmoAfeNR9xqBux0r1Q8Za60lavYmz=ctNJFf55vVA%3D&WGewmoAfeNQ16B2MHuCpMRKZMwaG1PaO=ctNJFf55vVA%3D|publisher=Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council|accessdate=24 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="HillingdonNodalPoints">{{cite web|title=Consultation Findings: School Admissions Criteria|url=https://modgov.hillingdon.gov.uk/documents/s30734/Detailed%20Consultation%20Responses%20Council%20Response.pdf|publisher=London Borough of Hillingdon|accessdate=24 August 2017}}</ref> They are also used by schools which are not located within, or near the centre of, the area that they are intended to serve,<ref name="EalingFields">{{cite web |title=Admissions |url=https://ealingfields.org.uk/attending-our-school/admissions |publisher=Ealing Fields High School |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref><ref name="OSAreport2016">{{cite web |last1=Scott |first1=Shan |title=Office of the Schools Adjudicator Annual Report, September 2015 to August 2016 |url=https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/585915/OSA_Annual_Report_2016.pdf |website=Office of the Schools Adjudicator |publisher=Department for Education |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref> or by schools which have opened at a temporary location, pending a move to a permanent site.<ref name="OneDegreeAcademy">{{cite web |title=One Degree Academy Admissions Policy |url=https://new.enfield.gov.uk/services/children-and-education/one-degree-academy-admission-criteria-2019-children.pdf |publisher=One Degree Academy |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref> Some schools that are intended to serve a wide area, or several dispersed areas, use transport hubs such as train stations as nodal points.<ref name="BBCBirmingham">{{cite news |last1=Coughlan |first1=Sean |title=One school, four catchment areas |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-32412744 |accessdate=23 November 2018 |publisher=BBC}}</ref><ref name="HealthFuturesUTC">{{cite web |title=Admissions Policy and Procedure |url=http://www.healthfuturesutc.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Admissions-Policy-Procedure-2018.pdf |publisher=Health Futures UTC |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref> Nodal points have also been used to ensure a mixed socio-economic intake.<ref name="BristolScrutinyDoc">{{cite web |title=School Admission Arrangements in Bristol |url=https://democracy.bristol.gov.uk/documents/s11614/04a.%20Different%20Admission%20Systems.pdf |publisher=Bristol Local Authority |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Education policy in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Education in England]]

{{Infobox university |name = Northern School of Contemporary Dance |latin_name = |image_name =Northern School of Contemporary Dance, Chapeltown Road, Leeds - geograph.org.uk - 108563.jpg |image_size = |motto = |mottoeng = |established = 1985 |type = [[Contemporary dance]] school |endowment = |staff = |chancellor = |director = |principal = Janet Smith |rector = |students = Approximately 200 |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |colours = |city = [[Leeds]] |country = [[United Kingdom]] |coor = {{coord|53.8132|-1.5333|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline,title}} |campus = |free_label = |free = |affiliations = [[Conservatoire for Dance and Drama]]
[[University of Kent]] |website = http://www.nscd.ac.uk |logo = }} The '''Northern School of Contemporary Dance''' ('''NSCD''') is a higher education institution in [[Chapeltown, Leeds|Chapeltown]], [[Leeds]], England specialising in [[contemporary dance]]. It is an affiliate of the [[Conservatoire for Dance and Drama]], and students can obtain a Bachelor of Performing Arts (B.P.A.) degree, validated by the [[University of Kent]]. A foundation course and postgraduate qualifications are also offered, and a programme of adult, youth and children's classes is available for the local community. ==History and buildings== The school was founded in 1985 by [[Nadine Senior]] MBE and in 1987 it moved into its current premises, a red-brick former synagogue on Chapeltown Road built 1929-1932. The building is grade II [[listed building|listed]]{{National Heritage List for England |num=1255639 |desc= The Northern School of Contemporary Dance |grade=II |accessdate=21 February 2014}} as are the boundary walls, which probably date to about 1835.{{National Heritage List for England |num=1255641 |desc=Wall gates and piers to north east and west of Northern School of Contemporary Dance |grade=II |accessdate=21 February 2014}} Between 1987 and 1997, a series of phased developments were carried out which extended the site to include the adjacent Brandsby Lodge,{{cite web|url=http://www.nscd.ac.uk/view.aspx?id=20|title=About us; History|publisher=NSCD|accessdate=21 February 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224131421/http://www.nscd.ac.uk/view.aspx?id=20|archivedate=24 February 2014|df=}} also a grade II listed building.{{National Heritage List for England |num=1255632 |desc= The Northern School of Contemporary Dance |grade=II |accessdate=1 April 2014}} This £3.2 million redevelopment, which resulted in the creation of four new dance studios and additional teaching facilities, was completed with funding support from the National Lottery through the Arts Council of England and the Foundation for Sports and the Arts.{{cite web|url=http://www.nscd.ac.uk/view.aspx?id=88|title=About us; History; Timeline|publisher=NSCD|accessdate=1 April 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228151822/http://www.nscd.ac.uk/view.aspx?id=88|archivedate=28 February 2014|df=}} In 1988, the converted Synagogue re-opened its doors as The Dome Theatre and in 1993 was renamed The Riley Theatre in dedication to the memory of Jeffrey Riley, who was the School’s Technical Director between 1985 and 1993. Founding Principal Nadine Senior MBE retired in 2001 and was replaced in 2002 by Gurmit Hukam. A year later, in 2003, NSCD became officially affiliated to the Conservatoire for Dance and Drama.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdd.ac.uk/affiliate-schools/nscd/|title=Affiliate Schools; NSCD|publisher=CDD|accessdate=1 April 2014}} In 2012, Janet Smith left her position as Artistic Director of Scottish Dance Theatre to become the current principal of the School. ==Vocational training== NSCD offers full-time vocational training in contemporary dance at foundation, degree and postgraduate diploma/MA level.{{cite web|url=http://www.nscd.ac.uk/view.aspx?id=230|title=Courses; Our courses|publisher=NSCD|accessdate=1 April 2014}} The training includes classes influenced by the techniques of Cunningham and Graham, the more modern hybrid, evolved techniques and release based techniques as well as complementary training in ballet, yoga and fitness.{{cite web|url=http://www.nscd.ac.uk/view.aspx?id=233|title=Courses; Our courses; BPA (hons) in Contemporary Dance; Technique and Performance Practice|publisher=NSCD|accessdate=1 April 2014}} ==Centre for Advanced Training== In 2004, with funding support from the Department for Children, Schools & Families’ Music and Dance Scheme, NSCD and [[Northern Ballet]] came together to establish Yorkshire Young Dancers (YYD), the first national dance Centre for Advanced Training (CAT) in the UK.{{cite web|url=http://www.nscd.ac.uk/view.aspx?id=640|title=Community Programmes; Yorkshire Young Dancers (YYD) National Centre for Advanced Training|publisher=NSCD|accessdate=1 April 2014}} There are now a total of 10 dance CATs offering pre-vocational dance training to young people across the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaldancecats.co.uk/|title=National Dance Cats|publisher=National Dance Cats|accessdate=1 April 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.nscd.ac.uk}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.education.gov.uk/edubase/establishment/summary.xhtml?urn=133840|title=Northern School of Contemporary Dance|work=EduBase2|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=21 February 2014}} *[https://www.hedd.ac.uk/viewInstitution?id=76 NSCD] at Higher Education Degree Datacheck *{{cite web|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/38398/northern-school-of-contemporary-dance-spring|title=Northern School of Contemporary Dance Spring Showcase|last=Berry|first=Kevin|date=4 April 2013|publisher=The Stage|accessdate=21 February 2014}} ''Review of showcase performance'' *[http://www.cdd.ac.uk/ CDD official website] *{{cite web|url=http://www.nscd.ac.uk/MODULES/NEWS/NSCD_NEWSmoduleASP/NEWSMOD_newsitem.asp?itemid=216|title=Janet Smith announced as new principal of NSCD|last=Brierley|first=Ceri|date=15 November 2011|publisher=NSCD|accessdate=1 April 2014}} ''NSCD news release'' *[http://www.nationaldancecats.co.uk National Dance CATs official website] {{Conservatoire for Dance and Drama}} {{Performing Arts Schools in the United Kingdom|dance}} [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1985]] [[Category:Performing arts education in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Contemporary dance in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Dance schools in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1985 establishments in England]] [[Category:Education in Leeds]] [[Category:Listed buildings in Leeds]] [[Category:Grade II listed buildings in West Yorkshire]] [[Category:Grade II listed places of worship]] [[Category:Former synagogues in England]] {{UK-university-stub}} {{dance-stub}}

headquarters
revision.text:
{{Infobox dot-com company | name = OpenSesame | logo = Opensesame.color.tm.png | logo_size = 180px | company_type = [[Online education]] | type = | foundation = 2011 | founders = | dissolved = | location =1629 SW Salmon Street, Portland, OR 97205 | locations = | incorporated = | key_people = Don Spear, Joshua Blank, Aaron Bridges, Tom Turnbull | industry =eLearning | products = | services = | company_slogan = | url = {{URL|https://www.opensesame.com}} | ipv6 = | alexa = | website_type = | advertising = | registration = Required | num_users = | language = | launch_date = | current_status = Active | screenshot = | caption = | footnotes = | intl = }} '''OpenSesame Inc.''' is a [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]] based educational technology company that provides an online marketplace for buying and selling [[SCORM]] e-learning courses focused primarily on employee training. Its online training platform, directly connects content providers with employees and businesses for online training resources and specially designed courses for professionals, which can be accessed through a [[Learning management system]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.learningsolutionsmag.com/articles/573/opensesame-unlocks-an-open-marketplace-for-e-learning-at-devlearn-2010 | title=OpenSesame™ Unlocks an Open Marketplace for e-Learning at DevLearn 2010 | publisher=Learning Solutions Magazine | date=3 November 2010 | accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pdx.edu/profile/opensesame-making-magic-online-training-courses | title=OpenSesame: Making Magic for Online Training Courses | publisher=Portland State University | accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.atelier.net/trends/articles/opensesame-ambitionne-de-devenir-plus-grande-plateforme-de-elearning-entreprises_426893 | title=OpenSesame ambitionne de devenir la plus grande plateforme de elearning pour les entreprises | publisher=L’Atelier BNP Paribas | date=20 January 2014 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Manon Garnier}}</ref> The company was founded in 2011 and is headquartered in [[Portland, Oregon]]. As of January 2016, OpenSesame tracks around 20,000 courses from more than 300 vendors.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oregonlive.com/silicon-forest/index.ssf/2014/07/opensesame_out_on_its_own_work.html | title=OpenSesame, out on its own, works to upgrade 'e-learning' | publisher=Oregon Live | date=10 July 2014 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Mike Rogoway}}</ref>
==History== The idea to start OpenSesame came to the founders Don Spear, Joshua Blank, Aaron Bridges and Tom Turnbull in 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/blog/2013/02/meet-the-40-opensesames-josh-blank.html | title=Meet the 40: OpenSesame's Josh Blank VIDEO | publisher=Portland Business Journal | date=7 February 2013 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Andy Giegerich}}</ref> They founded the company on the idea to aggregate fragmented elearning content from reputable publishers and resources including [[FranklinCovey]], Cegos and Wiley through a Learning Management System (LMS).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.silkroad.com/event/silkroad-partners-opensesame-deliver-personalized-elearning-solution/ | title=SilkRoad Partners with OpenSesame to Deliver Personalized eLearning Solution | publisher=SilkRoad | accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bluevolt.com/news/portland-based-technology-company-bluetech-llc-expands/ | title=Portland-Based Technology Company BlueTech, LLC Expands | publisher=Bluevolt | date=27 October 2010 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Kim Oates}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://elearningindia.in/e-learning-products/off-the-shelf-courses/ | title=Off the shelf courses | publisher=E-Learning India | accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> They worked on creating an ecommerce platform where any seller can add courses for sale and any buyer can purchase courses for use in their company's learning and development program.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oregonlive.com/silicon-forest/index.ssf/2014/07/opensesame_out_on_its_own_work.html | title=OpenSesame, out on its own, works to upgrade 'e-learning' | publisher=Oregon Live | date=10 July 2014 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Mike Rogoway}}</ref> They went through the [[Portland State University]] Business Accelerator and after conducting a few pilot trials, OpenSesame received seed funding of $2 million from Harmony Investments on October 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://siliconflorist.com/2011/09/12/opensesame-unlocks-2-million-funding/ | title=OpenSesame unlocks $2 million in funding | publisher=silicon Florist. | date=12 September 2011 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Rick Turoczy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.finsmes.com/2011/10/opensesame-raises-2m-funding.html | title=OpenSesame Raises $2M in Funding | publisher=FinSMEs | date=14 October 2011 | accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> The company soon gained some major clients including satellite TV giant [[Dish Network]], SilkRoad Technology, [[Five Guys Burgers]] and [[Fries]]. In January 2014 the company raised another round of Series A funding of $10 million led by [[Partech Ventures]] to create a corporate content delivery platform modeled after [[iTunes]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oregonlive.com/silicon-forest/index.ssf/2014/01/opensesame_portland_e-learning.html | title=OpenSesame, Portland e-learning startup, raises $8 million | publisher=Oregon Live | date=13 January 2014 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Mike Rogoway}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/01/14/opensesame-lands-8m-to-become-the-itunes-of-corporate-training-content/ | title=OpenSesame Lands $8M To Become The iTunes Of Corporate Training Content | publisher=TechCrunch | date=14 Jan 2014 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Rip Empson}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/blog/2014/01/what-is-opensesame-going-to-do-with-8m.html | title=OpenSesame's $8M will fuel employee growth in Portland | publisher=Portland Business Journal | date=12 January 2014 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Malia Spencer}}</ref> The marketplace allows the seller to set the price of the content, with a share in the profits for distributing through OpenSesame’s marketplace. On July 22, 2014 OpenSesame was granted US Patent Number US 8784113 B2 for their “Open and Interactive e-Learning System and Method.”<ref>[http://www.google.com/patents/US8784113]{{Citation|title=Open and interactive e-learning system and method|date=Jul 22, 2014|url=http://www.google.com/patents/US8784113|inventor-last=Bridges|inventor2-last=Day|inventor3-last=Blank|inventor-first=Aaron H.|inventor2-first=Jason S.|inventor3-first=Joshua D.|issue=US8784113 B2|accessdate=2017-11-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://siliconflorist.com/2013/05/02/oregon-technology-awards-names-cloudability-startup-year/ | title=Oregon Technology Awards names Cloudability "Startup of the Year" | publisher=Silicon Florist | date=2 May 2013 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Rick Turoczy}}</ref>
==Development== Since 2011, the OpenSesame development team has been focusing on the content and the development of features in line with the businesses' needs. The main concern of the company is not to build up a large number of new features on its marketplace, but to concentrate upon a few elaborated tools that can integrate with the various LMS’.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapid=24867918 | title=Company Overview of OpenSesame Inc. | publisher=Bloomberg L.P. | accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bentley.edu/impact/articles/companies-where-millennials-thrive-opensesame | title=Companies Where Millennials Thrive: OpenSesame | publisher=Bentley University | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Melissa Massello}}</ref>
==Use== OpenSesame is used in continuing professional development for employees and professionals via courses obtained online. Its platform allows companies to buy courses created by industry experts instead of having to create their own.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oregonlive.com/silicon-forest/index.ssf/2013/02/portlands_tech_renaissance_is.html | title=Portland's tech renaissance is great for software developers, not so for those looking to hire | publisher=Oregon Live | date=14 February 2013 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Mike Rogoway}}</ref> It allows businesses to search for courses offered by its sellers, they can preview the content, read reviews and know about the content seller.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.morningstar.com/news/pr-news-wire/PRNews_20160310SF43481/opensesame-announces-training-jam-in-portland-oregon-april-2224.html | title=OpenSesame announces Training Jam in Portland, Oregon April 22–24 | publisher=Morning Star | date=10 March 2016 | accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/blog/2014/10/why-opensesame-takes-a-chance-on-inexperience.html | title=Why this startup takes a chance on inexperience | publisher=Portland Business Journal | date=30 October 2014 | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Malia Spencer}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://trainingmag.com/trgmag-article/online-vs-class-success | title=ONLINE VS. IN-CLASS SUCCESS | publisher=Training magazine | accessdate=24 April 2016 | author=Lorri Freifeld}}</ref>
==Accessibility== OpenSesame is the first marketplace to comply completely with the accessibility specifications of [[Sharable Content Object Reference Model]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2011/02/prweb5021574.htm | title=OpenSesame Connects Enterprise Learners to Millions of Videos | publisher=PRWeb | date=3 February 2011 | accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://litmos.zendesk.com/entries/23032882-About-SCORM-Modules | title=About SCORM Modules | publisher=Litmos | date=31 January 2013 | accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> The content is also designed for adaptability to any of several teaching and learning scenarios with a variety of authoring tools compatible to any learning management system and custom business tools.
==References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * {{official website|https://www.opensesame.com/}}

revision.text:
: ''Rapira is also a name for the [[T-12 antitank gun]].''
'''Rapira''' ({{lang-ru|Рапира}}, rapier) is an educational [[procedural programming]] language developed in the [[Soviet Union]] and implemented on [[Agat computer]], [[PDP-11]] clones (Electronika, DVK, BK series) and Intel-8080/Z80 clones (Korvet). It was an interpreted language with dynamic type system and high level constructions. The language originally had a [[Russian language|Russian]]-based set of keywords, but [[English language|English]] and [[Moldovan language|Moldovan]] were added later. Also, it was more elegant and easier to use than existing Pascal implementations of the time{{According to whom|date=October 2015}}.
Rapira was used in teaching [[computer programming]] in Soviet schools. The programming environment included a text editor and an integrated debugger.
Sample program: ПРОЦ СТАРТ() ВЫВОД: 'Привет, мир!!!' КОН ПРОЦ
The same, but using the English lexics [sic, from the article referenced below]: proc start() output: 'Hello, world!!!'; end proc
Rapira's ideology was based on such languages as [[POP-2]] and [[SETL]], with strong influences from [[ALGOL]].
Consequently, for example, Rapira implements a very strong, flexible and interesting data structure, so-named 'tuples'. Actually, tuples in Rapira are heterogeneous lists with such allowed operations as indexing, joining, length count, getting of sublist, easy comparison, etc.
==External links== *[http://ershov.iis.nsk.su/archive/eaindex.asp?did=7653&lang=2 Description of Rapira] at [[Andrey Ershov]]'s archive *[https://github.com/freeduke33/rerap2 ReRap2] An interpreter for the English dialect of Rapira *<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:Rapira-EN.pdf | PDF collection of all the above images]] -->
[[Category:Non-English-based programming languages]] [[Category:Pascal programming language family]] [[Category:Procedural programming languages]] [[Category:Structured programming languages]] [[Category:Educational programming languages]] [[Category:Computing in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Soviet inventions]] [[Category:Programming languages created in the 20th century]]
